text:
Finally I've found the recipe for basic, restaurant style Mexican rice.  The key to this recipe is the seasonings you use.  I tried it as written, just with the cumin, and it was not nearly as good as it was when I did it a second time using Taco Seasoning I (from this site).  I just sprinkled in what looked like enough, about 1-1/2 tsp.  This mixture includes cumin and many other spices which are perfect for this recipe.  I also cooked my onion in the oil BEFORE adding the rice to get it nice and soft.  Other than that, I followed exactly as written and it was perfect!

text:
For the reviewers having trouble with browning and puffing the rice: My rice browned, but didn't puff. When I added the soup stock and tomato sauce, I was concerned (I had company over and this was the first try) but the rice came out beautifully, and puffed out. Don't let the other reviews prevent you from trying this simple and delicious dish. It made a great side dish for the quisadillas I made. This is also a good guy-proof recipe, considering I didn't mess it up. I'm definitely making this one again. I have a rice cooker, but I decided to take a chance and make it in a medium sauce pan, and I was glad. My rice cooker tends to singe the outer layer of rice. Cook hard!

text:
If you're looking for a Mexican Rice recipe that will be "the star of the show," this is not the recipe. If, however, you're looking for a pleasantly and subtley flavored Mexican-style rice to accompany a spicier main dish, this fits the bill perfectly. I chose to saute the rice in butter rather than oil, but otherwise followed the recipe as directed.  Don't worry about "puffing" the rice-just saute it till golden brown, then add the chopped onion and spices, saute another minute or two, then add liquids. Cover and simmer till liquid is almost absorbed and rice is tender. Nice, basic rice recipe.

This is a great basic rice recipe that is easy to prepare.  The only difference between my preparation and the recipe's is that I sauteed the onion before cooking the rice, added fresh minced garlic, and used chicken stock versus broth.  Thanks for submitting it.

text:
This has become our families favorite Mexican rice.  I made several alterations though:  used sea salt (to taste) instead of garlic salt and added 2-3 cloves of garlic (crushed), omitted the cumin, and added 1 packet of "Sazon Goya-Con Cilantro y Tomate."  It really adds to that authentic flavor you get in the best Mexican restaurants.  The cook time is accurate, but I find that the last 5 min, I need to add a dash of broth to keep it from being too dry.

text:
A strong chicken broth is needed to make this good. KAET: I've never been able to get my rice to brown and/or puff in a skillet either, so I always use my rice cooker instead. I saute the onions, minced garlic and cumin in a skillet, then throw it into the rice cooker along with the 1 c. rice, 1-1/2 c. chicken broth and all the other ingredients, omitting the garlic salt. The cooker shuts off when the rice is done. Easy and very good too.

text:
Don't let the name intimidate you.  I am a chef at heart not by trade.  I am of Mexican heritage and was the only one of 5 girls to learn to cook like Mama.  This recipe is very close to what I learned to make from my mother.  Slight differences are that we add a little less onion about 1/8 of a cup and we add about the same amount of chopped bell pepper that is added with the onions about half way through the sauteeing of the rice.  Instead of garlic salt we use granulated garlic or fresh garlic which will add a little more flavor.  We also add a dash of black pepper.  If you don't have fresh chicken broth that is already salted, we use 2 cups water and about 1 1/2  Tblsp powdered chicken boullion by Knorr Suiza found on the Hispanic aisle which has lots of salt in it, no need for extra salt. I'm not sure about adding taco seasoning as other reviewers have suggested, this makes me think of Fast Food Bell rice.  Homemade Mexican rice is not supposed to be over flavored, the main dish should have the flavor and or the salsa that you serve should be as spicy as you desire.  These flavors should not be expected to be in the rice.  I'd say this is a darn good recipe for anyone wanting to make homemade Mexican rice!  My chef hat off to Mommyto2!

country:

text:
This is an incredibly easy, delicious recipe.  I can't think of anything to give it other than 5 stars.  I did add 1 tsp minced garlic and since I did not have garlic salt, I used 1/2 tsp garlic powder and a dash of salt with delicious results.  I do recommend the rice cooker for rice dishes. If you have one, try it.  I love the rice cooker because its easy and fool proof.  Sometimes rice can be a pain, so if you are looking to impress, take no chances...just don't eat the thin, scorched layer on the bottom! If you do prefer the stove, here are some tips. 1. Your rice is NOT going to "puff" while being sauteed.  I don't know why it said that.  Rice will puff, or cook rather, when its completely submerged in liquid. Instead, the first step is meant to give it a more golden color in the end. 2. If you find your rice more "wet" than you'd like, leave on simmer but take off the cover.  It will evaporate the extra liquid. 3. To make rice soft: Don't take off the cover while cooking, let your rice stand for about 10 minutes after cooking, then fluff with a wooden spoon, and let stand again for 5 more minutes. 4. If its still not soft enough to eat after cooking, re-cover and cook another 5-10 minutes and refer back to #3.  Hope this helps!

text:
Very good base recipe. Mine turned out nice and fluffy. I made sure to brown the rice pretty well (Medium heat is key) before adding the liquid. Don't be scared if it smokes a little in the beginning. Just keep stirring and of course, lower the heat when you feel the need. Once the rice is browned, i make sure the skillet is hot enough so that when i pour in the broth (carefully pls), it will make a bit of that hissing sound of water meeting heat. Very mild compliment to any tasty/spicy Mexican dish. Keeping this and will make again n again. Thanks Mommyto2!

text:
Yay to the AR Exchange for recommending this to me!  This is just what I was looking for and I'll be making it again :-).  The only changes I made didn't change any ingredients or measurements.  Since I don't buy garlic salt, I used fresh garlic and 1/2 tsp of sea salt. I did wash the rice, but then I always wash white rice, and I added the tomato sauce a couple minutes before adding the broth just to cook the tomato flavor a bit, but the measurements are great, as is the flavor!  Thank you so much for the recipe. UPDATE 2/28/09:  Just made this a second time and had to go by memory since my computer was down that day...STILL AMAZING!  The only thing I do differently, is to let it sit, covered, off the heat about 20 minutes after cooking has finished.  This time, before letting it sit, I added a cup of partially thawed, frozen sweet peas and carrots on the top and quickly put the lid back on, then fluffed and stirred to mix upon serving.  I liked the added flavors and texture.  I swear I'm addicted to this rice.

text:
This rice was excellent!! The only thing I did different was reduce to  1 1/2 cups of chicken broth and 1/2 cup tomato sauce (about half an 8 ounce can). I also added 1 chopped roma tomato. The liquid should not exceed twice the rice amount or the rice will be too mushy and liquid will not be properly absorbed. Instead of broth one can use water and 2 bouillon cubes. The rice came out perfect with those modification and feel free to view the photo. Thank you for the recipe!!

I am going to use some chilie powder next time to make it spicy.  I also will use Jasmine Rice next time.  Jasmine is a very good rice.  It is so light and fluffy.  Perfect for making this dish.  I like to serve it with my chicken enchiladas recipe that I got off this webdsite.  I also will serve it with tacos, and burritos.  Thank you for this recipe.  It is a family favorite.

text:
This recipe is pretty close to my recipe except that I brown the rice first and then I add 2 cups of chicken broth,cumin,garlic salt, black pepper, and then about 1/8 of a cup of tomato sauce. You don't want the tomato sauce to overpower the whole dish. I am of hispanic decent and this is the way my mother and her mother always made it.

text:
This is the same recipe that I've used for years, but with two additions: 1. I saute onion or chopped shallot in the oil, and then add the rice, which allows the onion/shallot to brown as the rice browns, and 2. I add 1/2 chopped cilantro to the cooked rice, just before serving. The recipe is quite good as written, though- and sometimes, you just want a good, basic version, so as not to "out-do" the rest of your meal. This is a can't-fail dish! :o)

text:
I've been making this rice for several years now. I love it. I usually make a few changes, but since I've made it so much and have followed the recipe exactly I feel confident enough to rate the original recipe as well as giving my spin. I omit the tomato sauce and add "Rotel" in its place. I also use fresh chopped garlic along with the garlic salt. Another tip (of course you already know this...) don't lift the lid while it's cooking!! Let the steam do it's thing and you'll have great rice.

Some of the mushiness dried up in the fridge overnight and it had nice flavour, though still not very Mexican-y.

text:
Very tasty rice.  One suggestion:  When cooking the rice in oil, cook it by itself until you get it golden brown and puffed.  THEN add the cumin and garlic salt.  If you add the cumin too early, it darkens the rice and you can't tell when it's done.

I made this as core recipe for making twenty five servings of Spanish rice for our Silver Anniversary dinner. This rice was first to vanish. This is a great start recipe.

The last time we had tacos for dinner my husband insisted we have Mexican rice with it.  So in a pinch I went out and bought the packaged stuff.  It was so gross that I vowed that I would NEVER again buy that stuff!  I am still having bad dreams about it ;)
So, I set out to find a quick and easy recipe and came across this one.  I made a few subs: chopped some fresh garlic and added it with the onion.  Used about 2 tsp. taco seasoning instead of the cumin and salt, and subbed veggie broth since we are vegan.  It was really good!  Hubs kept commenting on how good the rice was.  I even got my little ones to try(which is a huge feat!)  This one's a keeper for sure!

text:
This is a good basic recipe for Mexican rice.  We used it as a side dish and a topping for the Weeknight Skillet Fajitas recipe from this site.  The only changes I made to the rice were to cook the onions (with minced garlic and cumin) first (omitting the garlic salt) and added a small amount of diced jalapeños.  Unfortunately, the jalapeños made it extremely hot, so next time I will use diced mild green chili peppers.

For a dish with only 7 ingredients, this is simple AND tasty!!! I then added the spices followed by the broth and the tomato sauce.  Truly wonderful!!  My search for a simple mexican rice to accompany great Mexican main dishes has ended!!  Bravo!!!

text:
If you're looking for a perfect mexican rice recipe, look no farther!!  I have been looking for a recipe that would be close to what we get at our favorite mexican restaurant in AZ (Popo's in Glendale) and thought I'd give this a try.  I made this last night for my weekly "Fiesta Friday" dinner and it was incredible!  Everyone raved about how great it was!  I doubled my recipe and added garlic and a little bit more cumin, but one major change I made was to use BEEF BROTH instead of chicken...it was perfect!  Oh I also put the onions in with the rice while browning it to make sure they were nice and soft.  Make sure you take the time to brown your rice -- it made all the difference!!  It was fluffy, flavorful and muy delicioso!  With the change to beef broth, this was VERY close to Popo's rice.  Thanks to Mommyto2 from this mommyto4!!  Absolutely fantastic!  This will be a regular dish at our Fiesta Fridays!

text:
Very good and easy to prepare. I made this to put into layered burritos, but I think if I were to serve it as a side dish, I would probably added some mexican stewed tomatoes or something to it to give it even more flavor. P.S. For those of you getting brown colored rice instead of orange, this may be because the cumin is burnt; try adding the spices along with the broth and tomato sauce, instead of while the rice is browning.

omg this was SO delicious!  i took Valerie's Kitchen's advice about using Taco Seasoning I from here in place of the garlic salt and cumin.  bf said it was just as good if not better than his ex's mom's mexican rice and that's saying a lot bc she's from mexico and is an awesome cook according to him.. ty so much for the recipe! ~~UPDATE: making this again 2.5 years later i thought to myself this seems like a lot of oil and maybe i should reduce it.. but i kept the amount the same.. the broth made me worry that it was going to be too salty.. even though i didn't complain about it in my first review..  i did half water half broth.. i should have trusted myself from the first time and did everything exactly as i had done it before.. it needed salt.. which was easily remedied by sprinkling some garlic salt over it but next time i'll be sure to make it the way i did the first time.. i'm sorry for doubting the submitter and myself!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677174.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I make this rice all the time and what I do differently is use 1 can (14.5 oz.) diced tomatoes (do not strain away liquid, use that too) and garlic powder instead of garlic salt and use regular salt to taste.  I do not use chicken broth just plain water (1 1/2 cups).  When browning the rice, it will not puff in the pan.  It expands once it simmering in the pot.  I grew up eating this rice all the time and I decided to change from tomato sauce because that was all I could taste and using diced tomatoes gives it a nice light flavor/color and you can taste the rice as it all blends very nicely.  Try it, you'll like it!

text:
I loved this side dish and it tastes like my local restaurant's version too. 

After reading a lot of the reviews, I added my normal taco seasonings at the same time as the salt (I used fine ground sea salt) and cumin: 1/4 tsp of paprika, chili powder, garlic powder, onion powder, Mexican oregano, and a dash of cayenne pepper. 

I also bought the tomato sauce they sell on the Mexican food aisle of the grocery store, which only says tomato sauce on the container but seems a bit "amped" compared to the ones on the canned tomato aisle.
This recipe is definitely a keeper.

text:
I have always sucked at making any sort or Mexican rice. To the point I just resorted to the yucky box stuff. This recipe changed my rice making life! I think the key is to take your time browning the rice. I cooked it on a medium type heat for several minutes, stirring it frequently. Do not leave the stove unattended. Was just great. I did take others advice and used taco seasoning (and the cumin), and used salsa instead of tomato sauce. Either way, I don't think you can go wrong. My husband could not stop talking about it. Making it again tonight, gonna try the tomato sauce this time.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
this is definitely my go to recipe for mexican rice.  after making it several times, I have it just the way we like it at my house!
first, I saute the chopped onion in the oil till carmelized, and I use extra virgin olive oil.  once the onion is carmelized, I add the rice and toast it for a couple of minutes, before adding the rest of the ingredients.  in addition to the ingredients listed, I also sprinkle in some smoked paprika, gives it THE BEST flavor!!
lastly, after the rice is cooked, I drain and rinse a can of black beans, and add it to the rice till heated through
PERFECT beans and rice to serve with any mexican dish!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2689406.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a nice, basic side to serve with Mexican entrees. My hubs and I frequent a local Mexican restaurant that serves excellent rice with all of their entrees. Although not as good, this sure gives theirs a run for the money! Upon reading several reviews on here, it seems that many are having issue with browning / puffing the rice. If you follow Mommyto2's directions carefully, you shouldn't have any problem at all. I'm not sure my rice "puffed" up, but it did turn a nice golden brown color (which I think is key). After your rice is golden, sprinkle with the spices, stir quickly to incorporate and then add your onion. It should only take a minute or so for the onion to soften at which point you can add your liquids, cover, reduce the heat and start timing. Other than being slightly moister than the local restaurant's version, this is a dead on copycat. Thanks so much for sharing, Mommyto2. :-) this will be added to my regular rotation for sure!

text:
This turned out tasty, but just a couple of problems:  1.  After years of making risotto, I know that rice does not "puff" due to frying--liquid is required to make rice puff.  So your rice is not going to puff in step 1.  2.  This required as much as 2x as much liquid as specified in order to get the rice cooked past "al dente".  I was trying to make it for a dinner party and had to keep adding liquid.  Kinda stressful.  Everybody liked it, though.

text:
So, I made this for the first time while hosting a party.  Using a long grain brown rice, I scaled the recipe 3-fold and substituted McCormick's Taco seasoning which I buy in a large container from Costco.  I also used a can of tomato paste since I didn't have tomato sauce and adjusted with some water.  I also made it ahead in my dutch oven, then reheated about 1/2 hour before serving, again checking that there was enough moisture in the pot so it wouldn't dry out.  Everything else, I followed the same, and it turned out great!  The fact that my 11 and 8 year olds liked it was an additional benefit.  I will definitely make this recipe again!

userID:
3780445
Display Name:
Dana
isPro:
False
followersCount:
1
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
13
favoritesCount:
0
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674135.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I gave three stars because this is how I start out my mexican rice but I do some things differently.  I think mexican rice should be mildly flavored so it isn't necessary to add alot of extra seasoning as some reviewers added.  I have experimented many times with how much oil to use and 2 tablespoons is just right for cooking one cup of rice.  It important to saute your onions and garlic before adding the rice, otherwise by the time the onions are translucent the rice will be burned. Do not take the lid off as that interferes with the moisture and heat.  I have glass lids for my pan so I can see what's going on.  Towards the end I just shake the pan to prevent the rice from sticking.  Turns out perfectly every time.
Review:
Rating:

1372476
Display Name:
Amy Wilson Walworth

city:

text:
Let me preface this review with this: I normally buy the Knorr/Lipton taco rice for taco night or when I make other Mexican-style food. However, in efforts to save money, I decided to give making my own rice a shot. While preparing my taco meat, I typed Mexican rice into the search engine and VOILA, up came this one. With so many reviews & high star rating, I knew it couldn't be bad. I was VERY pleased with the outcome.  The rice browned nicely in the oil, although I may try olive oil next time since it's a bit more healthy. I only had tomato paste, so I added some water to make it saucy. No chicken broth, so I dissolved 2 bouillon cubes... along with the cumin, I threw in a few dashes of cayenne pepper. Instead of garlic salt I added liberal amounts of garlic powder (probably 1/2-1 tablespoon). I followed everything else as written - delicious! Quick & easy and the best part is: I know exactly what's in it. No high sodium, no preservatives. I will never buy ready-made again. Thank you!! :)

This is a great authentic Mexican Rice recipe! A Mexican friend told me how her mother makes Mexican Rice, and this recipe is almost exactly the same, except for the chicken broth. Some use water or half broth and water, but that is just personal preference. I like it with broth, since it gives a fuller flavor. But either way, this is a really tasty rice!

Another quick and tasty trick is to use a jar of salsa instead of the tomato sauce, onion, etc. Puree the salsa and broth( or water) in a blender and then add the mixture to the browned rice to cook. It gives great flavor and requires no chopping!

text:
Really good!  Of course I used 1.5 tsp of my trusty Emeril's Southwestern Essence for the spices.  Other than that, I followed the recipe as written. Be sure to watch your heat so the rice doesn't dry out (every stove is different). After fluffing the rice, put the lid right back on it to let it wet steam a bit more because there may be some crunchies at the bottom.  This is such a simple, tasty recipe that I'll never go back to the boxed stuff again!!  Will go great with the "Refried Beans Without The Refry" recipe also on this site.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/132783.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I modified this as well. It is an excellent base and as close to authentic Mexican rice as one can get.  I personally took out the cumin and garlic salt and replaced the tomato sauce w/ diced tomatoes. My rice did not "puff" during the browning process.  First I browned the rice, added onion, added chopped garlic cloves. Next I added the tomatoes stirred and cooked for a min then added liquids (water and chicken broth), then added salt for taste.  I prefer salt and garlic cloves instead of garlic salt, but if I didn't have cloves I would have added the garlic salt.  Family and friends love this and ask me to make it all the time.

Also hint...once you add everything and stir let it sit, maybe stir once to prevent buring right after you turn the burner off, but leave rice alone it needs to rest.

text:
This is a wonderful recipe ... perfect as it stands ... or easy enough to add ingredients to fit ones perferred taste.  I prepared exactly as described ... and though there was little browning or popping of my rice either, it didn't matter.  I just proceded after a few minutes of tossing around in the skillet and then softening the onion.  I also served this with the Chicken Enchiladas I recipe,the Red Enchilada Sauce and the Canned Corn Casserole found on this site. All combined for a very complimary and tasty mexican dinner, which ALL enjoyed.  ONE NOTE: if you choose to do all the recipes mentioned, and you boil your chicken for the enchiladas in water seasoning with chicken bouillon, you can simply use that broth for all the remaining preparations for these recipes where water is called for, but replaced with chicken broth/stock.  I highly recommend doing so for added flavor.  :O)

Wow I can't believe how easy it was to make this. I followed the recipe exactly and it turned out great! It was a great base recipe. The next time I tried it and added in the Taco Seasoning I(from this website 
    *  1 tablespoon chili powder
    * 1/4 teaspoon garlic powder
    * 1/4 teaspoon onion powder
    * 1/4 teaspoon crushed red pepper  
      flakes
    * 1/4 teaspoon dried oregano
    * 1/2 teaspoon paprika
    * 1 1/2 teaspoons ground cumin
    * 1 teaspoon sea salt
    * 1 teaspoon black pepper
Adjust how you like. I just eyed the seasonings. This time it turned out delicious!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674147.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Cooked the rice in oil then added a large minced shallot to soften, plus 1/2 tsp salt. Bloomed the cumin and 1/2 tsp garlic powder in the rice mixture before adding 1/2 cup of red enchilada sauce (since I was making chicken enchiladas). Used chicken stock instead of water and reduced the amount to 1.5 cups (2 cups made this rice too mushy). The garlicky shallot + enchilada sauce in place of tomato sauce really kicked up the flavors of this tasty side dish. Delish!

Rating:

dateLastModified:
2014-03-05T13:06:50.973
helpfulCount:
2
userID:
3731740
Display Name:
Lauri
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
8
favoritesCount:
212
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674160.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I love this Mexican rice recipe. And with just a few minor additions I would give it five stars. The first time I made it I liked it quite a bit but I felt it needed more texture. So I increased the onion to slightly more than 1/3 of a cup, and I add one rib of small-diced celery at the same time as the onion. (I also use just less than 1/4 t. of cumin, but that's because of personal taste). And with five minutes to go, I add tomatos (2 Roma tomatoes, cored and diced). Adding the celery and the tomato gives it more visual appeal and also a little more texture, but doesn't really change the taste. I think this is such a great base recipe that can be altered to accommodate anyone's personal tastes. I love that the end product looks restaurant-quality, but it doesn't much effort to achieve it!
Review:
Rating:
5

text:
This is the best recipe I've found on this site! I make it at least 2 times a week with dinner. My husband is from Mexico and he always asks me to make this side dish! I made it for my sister and her inlaws as well and she was calling me days later asking how to make this rice. Just make sure when you're cooking the rice you don't lift the lid to check on it while it's cooking! Or else it will come out mushy :( let it cook on low covered for 25 min and it will be perfect! Thank you so much for this recipe :)

text:
Y'ALL. I didn't even have all of the required ingredients, and this was PERFECT!

I live in Texas and I LOVE LOVE LOVE refried beans and rice that you get at (Tex)Mexican restaurants. I had resigned myself to believing that you just can't make that kind of rice at home. WRONG!

This was delicious. I will definitely make it again. Just like the restaurants.

Here's my adjustments:
Omitted onion (too lazy to chop right now...)
Used a squirt of ketchup instead of tomato sauce (weird right? it totally worked! I would reduce amount of tomato sauce in original recipe)
used rice from a boil in a bag pouch that I cut open.
added chili powder and paprika.

BOOM!

Thanks!!

Best Fried Rice I have ever had. I use 2-3 minced garlic cloves & regular salt because I don't have garlic salt. After I stir in tomato sauce; I transfer the mixture into a rice cooker add a cup of mixed frozen vegetables and chicken broth, stir and walk away. This makes it even easier. This is a popular re-occurring dish in my house. It's great to take to a pot-lock as my friends always ask me to bring it. They love it!

country:
None
text:
I had hoped this recipe would be like my favorite Mexican restaurant's rice - and I was not disappointed!! This was my first time attempting mexican rice, and the recipe was very simple. My mexican restaurant does not put onions in their rice, so that was the only change I made. I think the garlic salt should be 'to taste' because I had to add a bit more than it called for - some may prefer less. PERFECT MEXICAN RICE is right here. And to the people saying it's bland - Mexican rice isn't supposed to be a show-stopper. It is a simple side, not meant to have a ton of things added to it, like bell peppers - that's SPANISH rice! Just my two cents. :) MAKE IT!

text:
Exactly what I was looking for!  I wanted a simple side dish of Mexican rice, this was perfect.  As other reviewers suggested, I put the (finely diced) onion in first, used a diced clove garlic instead of the garlic salt, and only 1 TBS of tomato *paste* as I don't like it too tomato-ey. I used 2 tsp of Knorr's Caldo de Tomate, tomato bouillon w/ chicken flavor.  I couldn't stop eating the rice!  Paired with Buffy's Refried Beans from this site and I was in heaven.

I never could get the rice to puff up... one or two pieces did puff up almost like popcorn, but that was it.  I was really worried that it wouldn't turn out right.  Be very careful with your heat, because the rice can burn very easily.  I learned that the hard way with my first batch and had to start all over from scratch.  Don't worry if your rice doesn't puff up.  Mine didn't but it still turned out just like mexican restaurant rice.

text:
Love this recipe!! I make it almost exactly as written, with just a few changes to my liking ( I have made it as written too, just as good). The only things I do differently are: 1) instead of tomato sauce, I puree a can of mexican stewed tomatoes and use a full cup of that and 1 1/2 cups of chicken broth, 2) After the rice is done cooking in the pot, I will throw it in a skillet pan and toast it up a bit. So delicious!

text:
Very good recipe! I did modify it a bit due to not having Chicken Broth and tomato sauce though. I used Jasmine rice, a can of regular Rotel (drained) and "Better than Bouillon" Chicken Broth mix. This gave it a slightly saltier (just a little) and spicier (jalapeno's in the Rotel) taste. Next time I may go with mild Rotel, but either way it was delicious. Like other reviews, if the rice doesn't puff much when cooking in the veg. oil, the broth will certainly puff it up and make it perfect.

As is, this recipe gets a three. It's not bad but it was a bit bland for my tastes. text:
This is a simple yet delicious Mexican rice. I made a few changes, including using 3/4 of the amount of garlic powder instead of garlic salt and adding some onion powder and a little extra cumin. I kept the overall amount of liquid the same but changed the ratio of chicken broth and tomato sauce (a little less broth, a little more tomato sauce) and the flavor came out really nice. Also, the recipe says it makes 4 servings, but it's more like 5-6 hearty portions.

text:
My family really liked this.  It fluffed up much more than other Mexican Rice recipes that I have tried.  It makes a good backdrop to a flavorful meal.  I would like it to be more flavorful itself, but that is easily done with more spices. Instead of using chopped onion, I pureed the onion with a clove of garlic(I did not have the garlic salt and used regular salt) in a bit of the chicken broth.  I added it at the time suggested and let cook for a minute before adding the rest of the broth and tomato sauce.  Thanks for the recipe!

city:

None
text:
I just made this today and I have to say, this was pretty good. I had to substitute some things though. Instead of garlic salt, I just added a finely chopped garlic clove and a pinch of salt. And instead of regular tomato sauce, I used "El Pato" tomato sauce. It has a blend of spices and chilies that gave this rice a nice edge. And since I didn't have any chicken broth, I made my own using a chicken bullion cube and boiling it in in 3 cups water. I decided to use a bit more water when I read other reviews about the rice not being fully cooked.

text:
This is really good for a quick side dish - better than Lipton or Rice-a-Roni, not as good as restaurant rice. It's easy to make and low on ingredients, which I like. I did use more diced onion than called for and chicken stock instead of broth because that's what I had on hand. For cooking time, instructions should be on your rice box. I used extra long grain brown, so I had to cook for 40 minutes.

text:
Just like the restaurant!  I recalculated it for 16 servings (Christmas dinner side).  Don't worry about it 'puffing' just toast the rice a little in the oil and continue on with the recipie-- it WILL turn out.  Very mild and basic, just authentic Mexican restaurants serve.  If you want to spice it up, knock yourself out and put whatever you want in it, but Mexican rice is usually very mild to balance the heat from the main dish.  This is a very good recipe and I know it will be devoured by all at Christmas dinner.  Mi gusta!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Simple and makes for a good side or an addition to a burrito.  Don't worry about the rice puffing up in the first step, it'll soak up plenty of liquid after the broth is added.  In fact don't be afraid to add some more water or broth during the simmer if you find it's all been absorbed and the rice is still a bit chewy.

text:
GREAT MEXICAN RICE!!!!  I have tried so many horrible recipes and now I have finally tried the one I will stick with!  My only suggestion would be to add the garlic salt and cumin to the rice right before it is browned because otherwise it gets kinda burnt tasting.  Also one of my favorite local mexican restaurants adds corn, carrots and peas to theirs and I really like that so I will be throwing those into this recipe as well.  Thank you so much for the fabulous recipe!  Also this goes great with the South Texas Carne Guisada recipe posted on this site - super yummy!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/18.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is my new favorite Mexican rice recipe, with a few alterations. I only use 1.5 cups of broth, so that the total amount of liquid is 2 cups, and I cut the cumin down to 1/4 tsp. I've even cut the oil down to 2 Tbsp, and it still comes out well! As for cooking the rice in the oil: cook it until it's opaque, and slightly golden. Don't worry about whether it puffs up or not; I think that part of the recipe is misleading. Other than that, great recipe, and I make it about once a week! Thanks!

I have tried and tried to find a recipe for mexican rice that tastes like authentic mexican cooking - none have come close...until now.  This recipe was so simple, and I was a little apprehensive about that.  The only thing I tweeked was that I added maybe 1/2 can of rotel (tomatoes, green chilies, cilantro, lime) which definitely added a kick as well as some fresh minced garlic.  My 21 month old loved this recipe!  I have made this several times!

text:
This is the best mexican rice!!! I did make a few modifications based on past reviews: I used 3 garlic cloves instead of garlic salt and added while browning the rice. I also used about 1 tsp of chile powder and added it and the cumin after the liquid. Instead of tomato sauce I used enchilada sauce, to give it a little kick. I only used 14oz of chicken broth instead of 16oz. It cooked for 25 minutes and was perfect, fluffy rice and great flavor. Thank you for a great recipe!!!

text:
this recipe made me (a transplanted texan in russia) feel like I was home again!  i browned the onions first, then added the rice- stir fry till fragrant (it will lose its transparent look... i think the "puffy" phrase is misleading.)  i only used 2 cups of liquid (1:2 ratio is a must in rice cooking!!)  i used a combo of chicken broth and reconstituted sun-dried tomato water and tomato juice. with a 1/2tsp of chili powder- this was perfect!

text:
Easy, quick and good!  I did use about half the oil called for, however, as the first 
time I made this I found it a bit greasy for my taste.  I had no trouble getting the rice 
nice and toasty-- it actually doesn't puff much at all, though it does go opaque (turns 
very white) then gets a bit brownish... I used jasmine rice for this and when toasts up 
it smells divine!  It's also good leftover.  Try this, you won't be sorry!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is exactly the way the Mexican ladies that I worked with made their rice. It is not supposed to be “spicy”. They commented that  white people thought all Mexican food was spicy and had cheese on it. If your rice was still hard your heat was not high enough for your rice to cook. The rice is always first cooked in a little oil because it keeps the grains of rice from sticking together. Hope these comments help. This is really a fool proof recipe.

text:
I like that this recipe keeps it uncomplicated.  I used butter rather than oil, and I used a red onion since that's what I had on hand.  If I use this recipe again I'll stick with the oil and use a yellow onion.  I'd also omit the cumin, and use minced garlic rather than garlic salt. I think that would keep it a bit lighter, like I prefer for rice.

Review:
Rating:
4
dateLastModified:
2013-05-26T22:35:08.44
helpfulCount:
1
userID:
11445157
Display Name:
Teresa
isPro:
False
followersCount:
1
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
3
favoritesCount:
3
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1015183.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I just made this rice today and it turned out great!  The recipe is pretty spot on.  The only things I did different were I added the onion to the skillet first and sautéed just until they were opaque, then added the rice.  Rice will not "puff up" without liquid so you can only sauté it till it's golden.  I added a little more tomato sauce since I just added the whole can (it was a small can), so it was probably about 3/4 cup instead of the 1/2 cup that the recipe calls for and I added a whole tsp. of Cumin.  I cooked it for 25min with the lid on and the removed it from the heat and took the lid off - but did not touch it yet.  You have to let rice stand for a little bit so the moisture can escape - about 10min.  Then I fluffed it with a fork and then let it sit a little longer so it could completely dry, that way you don't have wet sticky rice.  The rice went great with my beans and enchiladas :)

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a great recipe.  We are NPC bodybuilder/bikini competitors and rice (brown and white) are staples in our diet.  I was looking for a yummy off-season rice that would go great with our chicken, steak, and veggies. (found it works well with fish too).  Saute the chopped onions, with the prechopped garlic for a few mins then add the rice.  I sprinkle the rice with taco seasoning while I'm sauteing it along with the onions and garlic.  Add chicken broth, SALSA, bring to a boil and cover it.  The first time I made it I had to keep adding salsa &/or broth because it cooked down very quickly even on low.  Really good.  We add chipotle shake spice and cayenne to taste.  Made with the pollo fajitas recipe from this site.

text:
We found the recipe as written is just ok.  It was a little too bland for our taste and overall just tasted like ketchup. However, once we changed the ketchup to chili sauce and reduced the amount from 1/2 to 1/4 cup and added a few dashes of Franks Red Hot Sauce, it became a great mexican rice recipe.  We now make it, with those changes, at least once a month!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I didn't have garlic salt on hand so I googled and found a recipe for making your own garlic salt with 3 parts salt and 1 part garlic powder. So I did just that-- 3/4 teaspoon salt and 1/4 teaspoon garlic powder. In short, I think that was too much salt as the rice came out slightly salty. Had I used off the shelf garlic salt, the rice would have come out perfect. 
So if you don't have garlic salt handy, I suggest you use a little less than 3/4 teaspoon salt and 1/4 teaspoon garlic powder.

text:
Love this rice. I make this all the time. I turn into a meal though. While the rice cooks, I tend to fry up some ground beef, pork or chicken with taco seasonings or whatever seasonings I have around. I also make my own beans at home so I'll throw some pinto beans or black beans into a sauce pan to heat. When the rice is done, I'll throw the drained , cooked ground meat and the cooked, drained beans and corn into the rice and mix it all up. We eat it with tortilla chips or homemade tortillas.

country:
None
text:
Easy and delightful. Uses ingredients on hand. I've wrecked so many attempts at Mexican rice that I was amazed when this turned out tender, fluffy, savory, flavorful, but not spicy. Did make some substitutions -- butter instead of oil to give more savory flavor; 1 full tsp taco seasoning instead of cumin which I didn't have (but cumin was 1st ingredient in the taco seasoning packet from Trader Joe)....otherwise followed recipe to the letter. BTW, I didn't think the rice "puffed" as stated in the recipe, but it did turn a deep golden -- which gave it a LOT of flavor.

city:

None
country:
None
text:
The ingredients for this recipe are bacially ok, but I just use a dask of cumin, cumin is a spice that can be over powering. I use a teaspoon of dried oregao, no garlic salt, and regular ground garlic powder, I also use finely chopped onion, dried parsley, and instead of so much tomato sauce, I like to take diced tomatoes that you put through a blender, or use a molcaquete(stone motar), if you have one. and the juice..it makes for a much better taste, than if you use so much tomato sauce. then when it begins to simmer, drop in a very fine chopped piece of carrot and a few frozen peas for a final touch..This is Spanish rice as it is made by mexican cooks.

text:
So, I was born in southern california and lived a good portion of my childhood in Tucson, AZ...right next to the mexican border.  It basically goes without saying that I absolutely LOVE authentic mexican food!!  When I even see a Taco Bell commercial I instantly feel slight anger and a twinge of indigestion within.  ANYHOW, all of that to say that I made this recipe for the first time tonight and loved, loved, loved it!  I have made mexican rice many times before, but never using this method. I'm very pleased with the ease and taste of it!  Even my husband, who doesn't care for rice, raved about it!  :)

My only deviations were that I used 3/4 t sea salt and fresh minced garlic instead of garlic salt AND because we are vegetarian I used "Not Chick'n Broth" to make 2 cups as the recipe calls for.  It was delicious with my family recipe enchiladas!

This was fantastic - with my modifications. I added about a half tsp. of fresh garlic, a quarter tsp. each of cayenne pepper and chili powder and 1 tsp. of paprika. I also added about 1 tbsp. of fresh parsley, half a sliced yellow pepper and half a sliced green pepper. As the rice came to boil I added about a half can of diced tomatoes (minus the juice). I served it with homemade enchiladas, sour cream, refried beans and mashed avocado and it was divine!!!

text:
YUM!  I've been looking for a good Mexican Rice recipe that would taste like the kind you get in a Mexican Restaurant and this is pretty close!  It is slightly dry (in a good way) and lightly flavored so as not to overpower whatever dish it is being served with.  
I followed the recipe exactly except for using medium grain rice cuz that is what I had in my pantry and it turned out fine.  I will definitely make this my go to recipe for Mexican night in my house!

text:
This is my go-to mexican rice recipie using a few alterations after reading the reviews! 

I sautee about 2 cloves garlice with 1/4 chopped red onion, 1tbs olive oil and the cumin for a few minutes. Meanwhile, I add 1.5 cups chicken broth, 1 cup brown rice and a can of rotel to my rice cooker. Then I add the onion/garlic/cumin to the rice cooker and let it do it's thing! My husband loves this :)

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
This is the second time i've made this recipe and I absolutely love it.  I use it as my base in a Chicken Cheese and Rice recipe i'm copying from my favorite restaurant.  After reading the reviews I added the onions first and I use half a large onion as opposed to just 1/4 cup.  I also use Swanson's Organic Chicken Broth, and add like a 1/2 a cup plus one heaping tablespoon of hunts tomato sauce.  And it comes out perfect very moist and delicious.  For those who are concerned there rice isn't browning or puffing.  It won't be significant in a long grain rice.  Unlike an arborio rice.  It will just look slightly plump and will have a pink opaque color.  You just don't want to burn the rice :)  And On my stove on simmer 23 minutes is perfect :)  Ok, lol now that i've given you all this silly information I hope you love this recipe like I have :)  Also if you are looking for a good store bought white queso instead of making it yourself Gordo's White Queso is perfect and theres a dollar off coupon on their website.

text:
I have been trying to make Mexican rice for years and finally this recipe was the one! The rice does not fluff in the browning in oil process, but not to worry - it does fluff in the steaming process. Also, I would recommend adding the garlic and cumin after the onions because they tend to brown too quickly. Otherwise, a perfect recipe for Mexican rice!

text:
So good and easy!  I've never sautéed rice prior to cooking before, and I'm glad I tried this.  I thought I had tomato sauce before I started cooking but had to substitute at the last minute.  I tried a salsa/ketchup blend as it's all I had--it's still really good.  The ketchup makes it a bit sweet.  I also added some chili flakes with the cumin and garlic salt and the flavour is wonderful.  Over all this is a fantastic recipe and method for cooking rice.

text:
Very good! Tastes just like the restaurant rice, thank you for posting!! I did make a few adjustments in the hopes of making it slightly healthier. I did not cook the rice in oil- I just put the uncooked rice in the tomato sauce, chicken broth, minced garlic, chopped onion, and spices together. The rice soaked up the liquids very nicely. Once the rice was pretty much done, I added chopped green bell pepper, and let it sit in the steaming rice to cook a bit. Fantastic!

text:
I love spanish rice and this one is a good basic mexican rice recipe. I used the rice cooker to make the rice after I browned the garlic,added a dash of cumin, diced white onions and stirred with rice and salt in a small pot. Then I put it all in one rice cooker, added chicken broth, tomato sauce, a little salt and one stem of cilantro for flavoring and let it cook.

text:
I would've given this a 5 star review if it weren't for the directions.  I made this two times, once following the directions to the tee, and the other doing it my way.  I found the rice to be extremely sticky and absorbed too much water when I did it according to directions.  The second time I did it, I just threw everything in at the beginning and cooked the rice like I regularly do, which is to allow the water to boil, add the rice, and simmer until the water is absorbed.  Cover, and cook until done.  The rice tasted wonderful though.  I will make this again!

I made a few changes to add a little flavor &  because I'm picky.    I changed the following:    Added fresh chopped garlic to the oil before adding the rice.   Subbed 1 can of Rotel for the tomato sauce. I might try the spicy Rotel next time for an extra kick. (I used the immersion blender.I don't like chunks.)  Instead of chicken I used veggie broth.   I also used just 1 cup of broth since I used the whole can of Rotel. 10 oz can   I seasoned the rice before adding the liquids with; taco seasoning, chili con carne seasoning, pepper & cumin. I left out the garlic salt since I added fresh garlic.

text:
This is by far the best mexican rice I have ever had even better than at any restaurant I've ever been to. I followed the instructions but I also took the advice of some of the reviews and added some home tac seasoning(which on took 2 minutes to make) and I also added a pack of sazon. I also always make my own chicken broth out of hot water and chicken base(not cubes) whenever a recipe calls for broth. I add about one teaspoon of base per cup of hot water. I find already prepared broth is very flavorless. Next time I make this rice I will also add gondules bean(pigeon peas) they are wonderful in rice.

I'm mexican/puerto rican and this is just how my mom and dad make it, minus the chicken broth and ground cumin. Usually my parents just use water and fresh cloves of garlic, onion and tomato sauce.   I found this recipe to be a bit too salty though for my taste. Way more salty than what Ive come across in Mexican restaurants as well.   I like the addition of broth, it definitely adds more flavor. I wouldn't change anything in this recipe except maybe using fresh minced garlic instead of garlic salt and salting to taste if needed.    Thanks!

text:
I used crushed tomatoes as I was out of tomato sauce but I don't think that made a difference in taste other than a few chunks of tomato.   After it was cooked, I put it in a small casserole, topped it with shredded cheddar and put it in the oven until the cheese was melted.   I don't eat it but my husband said it tasted really good, just like the rice at the local Mexican restaurant.  I would definitely make it again.  Edit:  I just made it again and use Rotel diced tomatoes instead of tomato sauce and it was even better!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I will admit that I messed up my batch by adding chicken bouillion to water instead of using fresh chicken broth.  But i also modified the recipe to include only 1.5 c of water, which was perfect amount of liquid with the tomato sauce.  Besides over salting, I think this produced a texture that was a little mushier than I'm used to in rice.  Perhaps this is just how Mexican rice is supposed to be.  In the future, I will be trying 1.25 c of water in addition to the tomato sauce instead.  All aside, this is almost exactly like a deconstructed rice-a-roni mix.  Excellent recipe with modifications.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674138.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is just like the rice in my local authentic Mexican restaurant.  I did change a couple little items in the recipe.  I added abundant ground pepper with the other spices, and approximately double the amount of onions.  Also, instead of finishing this on the stove, I let it come to a boil then covered it and stuck it in the oven for 1/2 hour at 350*.  It comes out perfect this way, and no need to worry about it scorching on the stove.  I served with canned refried black beans simmered down with some chicken stock (I had extra) and blue corn chips.  Sabroso!!!

text:
Just what I wanted! I tripled the recipe, prepared it in a large stock pot. The suggestion for using aluminum foil as an extra cover under the lid worked great. I used tomato sauce from the Mexican section at the grocer which had a wonderul spicy "kick". I also added about a 1/2 cup of very finely chopped green pepper and 3 cloves minced garlic to my tripled recipe. I sauteed the onion in oil for a min. before adding the rice, garlic, & green pepper. I sauteed all these together while browning the rice. SO GOOD!

text:
This rice was good, but to me, it needed more flavor.  I am going to have to experiment with it to get it right.  First of all, putting this in a rice cooker was a disaster.  The bottom layer burned.  When I did it again stovetop, it turned out just fine.  I just had to watch carefully for all the water to be absorbed, because it didn't take the full amount of time, and I would have had more burned rice.  It was wonderful with Burrito Pie from this site for Cinco De Mayo, but I won't make it again as is.  For me, it just needs some more flavor.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/361419.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was exactly the kind of rice I was looking for to serve with Chile Verde in tortillas with black beans.  It's not too flavorful on its own, but with another spicy Mexican dish it can be perfect.  I did make a few slight modifications: I used a clove of garlic (minced) instead of garlic salt; I only used 2 Tablespoons tomato sauce, I added a dash of oregano and I used olive oil instead of vegetable oil to cook the rice in.  I wouldn't change a thing next time I make it.  But again, this isn't the type of rice you make when you want it to stand alone as a real spicy side dish.  If that's what you're looking for, then I would suggest adding some of the taco seasoning to it like another person suggested.

Display Name:
killerbeegurl

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1216341.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
You cannot mess this recipe up.  So easy and good!  I didn’t measure a thing (except the rice).  I put 1 whole chopped onion and 3 minced garlic cloves in a skillet with about 2 tbsp of butter on medium.  Then I added the rice and cumin about 5 minutes later. After that browned up, I added a small can of tomato sauce, which is actually double what the recipe calls for (I didn’t do this on purpose. I had one too many beers, I guess).  Then I added just 1 can of chicken broth (which I knew was going to be a bit too little).  When all the chicken broth was evaporated, I added about a ¼ cup of water (cuz you know I wasn’t gonna open another can of broth for only 2 ounces!!)  And, after everything…the rice was delicious!  I liked having the extra onion in there and doubling the tomato sauce turned out fine!!!  I’ll use this again for sure since it’s so easy and fool/drunk-proof.

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I came across this recipe and was very pleased with the results.  It is an easy recipe to follow and requires only ingredients that I normally have at the house anyway.  I cook as directed but use water and chicken bullion instead of the chicken broth.  Also, I find that the rice is a bit soggy when it is first done cooking, but if you puff with a fork as directed and let it set for a few minutes after, it will thicken up and taste delicious.  I use it to accompany all of my Mexican dishes including tacos, enchiladas, etc.

text:
I wasn't looking for a show-stealer: just something to go along with chicken fajitas - and it did the job wonderfully! I used basmati rice and chicken consomme instead of broth. I find cumin an odd spice for a "Mexican" dish and the flavor did seem a little out of place. The use of taco seasoning, as mentioned by others, would be a more appropriate fit and I'll try that next time. Oh, and my rice didn't fluff in the first stage of cooking - it just browned and still came out great.

LOVED this! I added frozen vegetables into the saucepan first and made sure they cooked a little before adding the rice, which added some great color and additional flavors. I also added a little Adobo seasoning to the garlic salt and cumin. Also, when I put in tomato sauce, I put in some salsa. text:
This is good rice, but it's missing something.  I'm from Texas, and down here, no Mexican dish is complete without cilantro!  This is a very important ingredient.  It adds a much needed kick to everything.  You don't need a bunch of it, just about 1/4 cup will be plenty.  If you're not familiar with it, just use a little until you get your taste figured out.  Just add it in when you add in the liquids.  It's great.

text:
Perfect 'as is.' What I also love about it is its versatility, in that you can add green peppers or a little more spice if that's your taste, and it turns out great. The only thing I do differently is saute my chopped onions at the same time as the rice to bring out their flavor. I've never had a problem with my rice browning and puffing; the only time I did was when I was forced to substitute parboiled or minute rice. For anyone complaining that it's too bland, rice is supposed to serve as a fire extinguisher for the other spicy/jalapeno/chile pepper items on your plate. This is the recipe I use all the time. Everyone loves it.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/397593.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Super good and easy!  I did change it some so I could use some of the tomatoes/produce from my garden and I loved it even more.  Changes I made were 1.) Rinse the rice in a colander for several minutes under cold water - to remove some of the gluten - then drain.  2.) Take about 3/4 c fresh tomato, cut into quarters, and about a 1/4 of a medium onion, sliced lengthwise - place on a cookie sheet, drizzle with olive oil and sprinkle with black pepper and place in a 450 oven until soft and roasted.  Set aside to cool, then chop. 3.) Saute the rice in olive oil and added a big clove of minced garlic and the cumin near the end of the browning process.  4.) Then added the chicken broth with 1 T. green chilies and 1 T. tomato paste.  5.) Add tomato/onion mixture to the rice near the end of the cooktime.  6.) and add a little cilantro and a squirt of lime when finished.  So good and I can taste all the freshness from my garden too.  Love it!

text:
I followed the recipe exactly, except that I substituted garlic powder for the garlic salt after reading reviews about the dish being salty.  This was a good move as there was exactly the right amount of salt for us from the broth.  The rice cooked up perfectly in about 40 minutes and had a beautiful texture.  The flavor was VERY bland.  If I make this again, I will definitely jazz it up with more cumin, some fresh garlic, some hot sauce and some minced peppers.  My kids really liked the bland flavor but the only thing I liked about it was the texture.

text:
This rice tasted great, hence the 4 star review, but mine came out super sticky. I followed the recipe pretty closely, except I sauted onion and garlic first and then skipped the garlic salt, and used chicken broth instead of water. Like I said, the flavor was great, but I think having to bring the liquid to a boil with the rice, instead of adding the rice to boiling water, made the rice very sticky. I made it for company and everyone had seconds, so it wasn't a big deal, it just wasn't exactly what I was expecting. I would make it again though, especially if I could figure out a way to change the consistency.

Display Name:
Loves 2 Cook!
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/182534.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this rice for a 9 year olds birthday party lunch, so I wasn't looking for it to be too spicy.  Instead of browning the rice in vegetable oil, I used Nucoa margarine (it's the only margarine that I've ever used that is impossible to burn).  The rice puffed up nicely.  I used garlic powder instead of garlic salt as I felt the chicken broth had enough salt in it.  After it was done, it still needed something so I added a 4 oz can of diced green chilies (this was for a double recipe of the rice).  The green chilies seemed to add just enough flavor to the rice, without it being too spicy for kids.  When I make this again, I plan on adding a 4 oz can of diced jalapeno peppers along with the 4 oz can of green chilies.  I'll update this review once I try the recipe again!

text:
This was a really good Mexican rice recipe.  I was really short on time so I did make a few adjustments.  I used the Success family size boil in the bag rice and boiled the rice in a mixture of water,chicken broth tomato sauce and the spices listed in the recipe.  After I took the rice bag out of the liquid, I added a little more tomato sauce and salt directly to the rice.  It was really great, and ready in about 10 minutes!

text:
The first time I made this rice, I followed the directions exactly. It was good but not great. The next time I made it I cooked the onions in the oil first, then added the rice. After about 5 minutes, I added 1 tbsp of taco seasoning (from this site) and 1 clove of fresh minced garlic. Instead of tomato sauce, I used 1/2 of a small can of tomato paste and half of a chopped tomato. Really great with my alterations. The only thing I would do the next time is cut the oil down by 1 tbsp.

Tastes great!  Trust what everyone says about the rice not puffing. I ended up microwaving for 10 mins. after it being on the stove top for 40 mins.  If I did it again, I would make the rice first and then mix into the rest of the ingredients.  Very good though!

text:
I really like this rice and my husband especially loves this rice. I have made this several times it has turned out great every time. I used 1/2 tsp garlic powder and 1/2 tsp salt because i didn't have garlic salt but it turns out well that way so i won't even try the garlic salt. Also, I think it only needs 2 Tbs of oil, sometimes it seems too oily with three. I don't think my rice puffs before adding the broth and tomato sauce, but it does brown. I add the onions at the same time as the rice because they have to be completely soft for my husband to eat them and they are done at the same time the rice is if you don't cook it at too high of a temp. Thanks for this great recipe, I wont go back to the boxed kind.

text:
Over the years, I have become well-known for "my" Mexican Rice -- this recipe! I use 2 teaspoons of cumin and salsa instead of tomato sauce, but otherwise keep the recipe the same. It is so versatile and delicious. Not only is salsa a great substitute for the tomato sauce, but you can also use V8, green salsa, tomato juice, tomato soup and it still turns out awesome! This is a keeper!

I used Mexican hot tomato sauce and more cumin than the recipe calls for.  Make sure while browning your rice you stir constantly or it will burn.  Also don't give up too early, let each grain of rice toast...that's what gives Mexican rice it's distinct flavor.

text:
I make this rice at least once a week to go with tacos/quesadillas/burritos. So yummy, and SO easy to make with my rice cooker. Just chunk it all in and flip the switch! My only adjustments are using mild salsa in place of tomato sauce, and my husband likes a little more cumin thrown in for flavor. Oh -- and since I am a vegetarian, I use vegetable broth. I made it one time with chicken broth, and to me there's virtually no difference. Thanks so much for this wonderful recipe.

text:
this rice was awesome! i followed the advice of another reviewer and used taco seasoning instead of the cumin. i enjoy really flavorful food so i added 1 tbsp of the taco seasoning instead of 1.5 teaspoons. i don't usually use chicken broth (it's expensive!) so i just put in 2 heaping teaspoons of chicken stock powder in its place along with 2 cups of water and omitted the salt. i used fresh garlic instead of the garlic salt, used an entire onion, and also added a chopped up red bell pepper. it was soooo good. i will definitely make this again. i served this with "chicken enchiladas II" from this website and my boyfriend raved.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2875837.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is the way I was taught to make my rice by my mom and grandmom but, throughout the years I've changed the way I make my rice--for example:  When my kids were young they didn't like to see anything in the rice but rice (bits of onion, tomato etc) so, I used powder onion,cumin,garlic etc and as they grew I would add mixed veg.for added nutrition, and other times I omitted the tomato sause,cook  rice as directed but at the end of the 20 min. of cooking I would add the cheese of my liking and let sit in the coveded pot for 5-10 min. and gently mix all together.  The things you can add to this rice is endless.  Just adjust the liquid accordingly.  Sometines I add a few spoonfuls extra of liquid for a moister rice specially if adding a veggie that absorbs more liquid.
Instead of tomato sauce you can add your favorite salsa for an added kick.  Try different things just keep with the rice/liquid ratio 1 part rice 2 parts liquid.  ENJOY

city:

country:
None
text:
We're getting there slowly.  I'm on the quest of finding the perfect, fluffy mexican rice for my DH who is Mexican-American.  His grandmother made the "best rice he's ever had" (of course!) and I'm trying to find something similar.  This one was fluffier than others and had great flavor (which from what I understand is supposed to be on the mild side, not strongly flavored).  I had no problem getting my rice to brown and puff.  I think some people are expecting it to puff like popcorn, and that's not the case.  What it does is swell slightly and go from being kind of clear-ish looking to being kind of pearly looking.  Good recipe and hubby is getting happier!

text:
Easy to Remember. Easy to Prepare. Extremely Delicious. Now reading those three phrases you might wonder why one would give a dish they speak so highly of only four stars. Well to be frank, I have tasted/prepared much better Mexican Rice but that isn't where the genius of this recipe lies. The brilliance of it resides in its straight forward nature which makes it perfect for someone who doesn't have a lot of time to spend in the kitchen. The reason for this is the fact that the recipe maker delivered exactly what they promised and that was Mexican Rice. I found that the ingredient amounts were spot on which really made for a very cohesive/well balanced dish although I did find myself adding a little crushed red pepper just to spice it up a tad but that was purely a personal decision. To sum this all up it may not be the best Mexican Rice dish I’ve ever tasted but it is Mexican Rice in its purest form: Rice, Garlic, Broth, Onions, and Tomato Sauce. Thank you for sharing Mommyto2!

text:
The rice turned out pretty good, but really mushy. I think next time I will omit the tomato sauce. I did add diced carrots, Goya Tomato and Cilantro seasoning (which makes the rice really orange by itself), and a small amount of Rotel (no juice) which really made the flavors pop! I will definitely make this again but tweak the recipe a little more. I gave this 3 stars because of the ingredents that I had to add, along with the fact that it was pretty mushy.

text:
Pretty good rice. I used vegetable broth as I was out of chicken and added aprox 1/2 tsp each of chili and garlic powder. I also used a can of rotel in place of the tomato sauce, and added a handful of frozen corn at the end for color. A good side dish to serve with mexican fare.

text:
I made this tonight, my hubby and I both enjoyed it.  I didn't have garlic salt, so I went with salt and some minced garlic with the onion.  Like others, I toasted the rice in a frying pan and added the onion/garlic there.  Once the onion was ready, I tossed it in my rice cooker with 1/2 c. salsa instead of tomato sauce, and only 1 1/2 c. chicken broth (per my rice cooker) along with 1/2 c. frozen corn.  I also added a little chili powder to the cumin.  I think next time I'll have to add at least one jalapeno for my hubby who likes his food spicy.  Thanks for the recipe!

text:
YUMMY! This recipe is SO good. I followed the advice of some of the other reviewers and substituted the tomato sauce for a drained can of tomatoes w/ green chilies. I also left out the garlic salt and replaced it with 1 teaspoon of kosher salt and 1 minced clove of garlic. Once everything was mixed together in the skillet, I threw it into my rice cooker and it came out perfect! Tasty, tasty!

city:

country:
None
text:
Although I have not tried this recipe, it is very similar to my own with the following differences. I don't use garlic salt. I never use garlic salt in any of my recipes. I like to control the salt a garlic flavors. Instead, I use 1 tsp of salt and 1/4 tsp garlic powder. I also add 1/4 tsp of pepper. I only use cumin if my wife is not in the kitchen. When she makes the rice, she doesn't add cumin. I believe cumin does make this recipe taste better. I also use one 8oz can of tomatoe sauce which is 1 cup instead of the 1/2 cup mentioned in this recipe. 1/4 cup onions...well I probably use more maybe 1/2 cup. I usually use one small onion or 1/2 of a large onion.
Cooking time is about right.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614261.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have looked all over for a recipe like this. It has a great flavor with the cumin, and there are no "chunks" for my kids to whine about and try to pick out. It complements other Mexican dishes well as the flavor is great and not too strong and overpowering, but not bland. The only change I make is to balance the amount of rice and liquid. It should be 1:2 (1 cup rice and 2 cups liquid; I use 1 1/2 cups broth and 1/2 cup tomato sauce) This allows the rice to cook properly and have the right consistency.

text:
I have been searching for a recipe for a Mexican rice dish for ages. This is the #1. I listened to other reviewers & added 1 T chili powder. I also added 1 can of Rotel tomatoes w/green chilis,in place of some of the tomato sauce & some of the chicken broth, as I make a double batch-I use the rotel in place of one can of chicken broth It added the spicy touch we love!Thanks, Sylvia for a super rice recipe!

text:
I've made this many times and I always get requests for the recipe.  If time permits, make this rice a few hrs ahead of serving.  The rice isn't as mushy if you let it sit for a while.  This is really great if you have to make it the night before and heat it up.  Also, once I used beef boullion instead of chicken broth and I think it was even better that way.

Topped it with reduced fat sour cream and some mild Taco Bell sauce (our favorite!) and it beat any restaurant rice, hands down! Thanks for the great recipe!

text:
This turned out pretty good for a basic Mexican rice. I used salt separately from garlic powder and minced garlic plus added pepper. The rice does not "fluff" when you cook it in the oil it just browns some, the fluffing comes after you add the broth and simmer it. Good side for a spicier more flavorful main dish.

I was looking for a healthy side dish to go with the Mexican meal I was cooking.  Instead of using rice, I used cauliflower rice, which I cooked, first, in the microwave for 9 minutes.  I also used chicken broth instead of vegetable broth and then followed the recipe as directed. I figured that substituting the rice, works in my risotto recipe, why not Mexican rice...It was very good; nice flavor. My husband and our guests really liked it. Will do this one again.

text:
Made mostly as directed. I only had a bag of a frozen blend: 3 peppers and onions, so I used that in place of the onion. This turned out amazing!! Only thing I will do different next time is add the onion/pepper mixture before the rice so I can brown them a bit. This recipe went astoundingly well with an "Easy Beef Enchilada" recipe I found from Pillsbury.

Update: This is my second time making them and I forgot to add the onion/peppers early. Lol but this time I added a can of rinsed black beans and made this my main course. Made a great lunch!

Sooo good! This was better than rice at our local Mexican restaurant. The only changes I encourage are saute the onion first until slightly golden and then add the rice. text:
This was very good and easy to make. I made a few changes based on what I had on hand. I added some chopped bell pepper for color and made enough for 6 people. The flavor was very good, but I did add a small amount of home taco spice (found on this site) along with the spices in the recipe. I didn’t have any garlic salt, so subbed garlic powder, intending to add salt, but I forgot to add it. That made the dish a little bland, but with the addition of salt, it was very good. I will make again. Everyone enjoyed this with our tacos, so I’m a happy cook.

text:
Just made this tonight (with a few tweaks with what I had in the pantry), and all of us loved this! 
First, I sauteed the onions in the oil, then added the rice (only had regular white rice, but it still was delicious). Then I added a can of chicken broth, a can of diced tomatoes with green chilies not drained, a 7.5 oz container of tomato sauce, salt, pepper, garlic powder, a bit of cumin, and some chili powder.
Topped with shredded cheese and sour cream. It went PERFECTLY with our tamales and beans. Will be making this one again soon!

I tried to follow it as written, but should have sautéed the onions first, as the rice got too brown while the onions were cooking.  The next thing, and may be I bought some old rice or something, but it has beeen simmering for 1.5 hours and some of the rice is still crunchy.  I was thinking that may have to do with frying it in oil first, which I know is the traditional Mexican way, but theirs is never crunchy.  Thinking about starting over before my company gets her in two hours.

text:
This tastes most like restaurant Mex rice!! I've made this many times and I have substituted salsa for the tomato sauce and it definitely brings the heat! :)  (however much you want, mild, medium, hot). I've also used rotel-type Tomatoes and chiles...oh, so good!  The key step is to do the oil and rice in the beginning, that will open up the rice grains to absorb the flavor....Cumin is my new secret ingredient ;)

text:
Wonderful easy recipe.  My family loved the flavor.  Reheats perfectly.   I did have to change the tomato sauce because I only had tomato paste.  I used 1 tbsp paste.   I hate to leave reviews on anything if I didn't follow the recipe exactly, but my change wasn't really anything important.  So if you are in a pinch, 1 tbsp of tomato paste works, too.   Just make sure to whisk it with some of the water from the recipe first.

text:
I added portabella mushrooms and fresh spinach to the other veggies and sauteed all before adding the rice. Threw some steak strips I'd marinated overnight (oil, brown sugar, garlic, and ginger) into a skillet when the rice was almost done and serves this on a four tortilla. On a whim, I added lemon slices to the plates, and when the lemon juice hit the rice--pure perfection! With all the veggies this made a generous amount of rice, but...not one grain left.  My family loved this dish.

Made this for Cinco Dr Mayo and it was a hit. I used real garlic and salt instead of garlic salt. I also used my rice cooker and out came out perfect. Added the garlic, salt and cumin and cooked another minute or so...then put it all in the rice cooker with the chicken broth and tomato sauce and turned the pot on. Perfection!)

text:
We loved this.  Because I was using up food on hand, I made several changes:
 - Substituted chopped fresh garlic for the garlic powder 
 - Substituted 12 oz. can chopped tomatoes for the tomato sauce
 - Added a small can of chopped mild green chilies
Like previous reviewers, I first browned the chopped onion, then added the fresh garlic and rice.
I'll definitely be making this again.  It was excellent.

text:
I made this to go with my black bean flautas. Ignore the word "puffed" when initially cooking in oil. When the rice is brown then you are good to with the rest of the recipe. Also, I paid attention to other reviews and sautéed the onion and a few cloves of garlic in the oil before adding the rice,  just a small can of tomato sauce, and water instead of chicken broth. This turned out GREAT!

I used really liked the base of this.  I  I doubled the recipe .  Tip and time saver is to blend the onion, tomatoe  sauce and a few garlic cloves in the blender with the stock. This base  is easy and delicious!

text:
So I've made this twice...the first time I made it to the letter of the recipe and it wasn't so great. The second time I wasn't paying close attention and it was a BIG HIT in the household! What did I do wrong? Well I guess that's a matter of perspective because it is definitely the way I will be making this recipe in the future. I STARTED WITH ALREADY COOKED WHITE RICE. Then I reduced the amount of chicken broth in half and cooked it on a little higher temp until it cooked down. It turned out so much better the kids even liked it! Great for Taco Tuesday!

userID:
979485
Display Name:
JKCOOKER
isPro:

10

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677173.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I agree that this is a good basic recipe for rice.  I made a few changes and would give it 4 stars with those.  Instead of the garlic salt/cumin I used a tablespoon of homemade fajita seasoning (I was making this with fajitas).  I didn't have any tomato sauce so I used 4T tomato paste with 1/4 cup of extra chicken broth.  I sauted the onion with some jalapeno and garlic then added the rice and toasted it.  I sprinkled that with the fajita seasoning and cooked for about 30 secs.  Then I added the rest and let it cook for 25 minutes.  The rice was still a little crunchy - so next time I might add 1/4 cup additional broth.  Overall it is an easy recipe and something you can adjust to fit what you have on hand.  Thanks!

text:
There were a few things I didn't like about this recipe, but feel like it could be good with some adjustments. 1 tsp of garlic salt makes this recipe entirely too salty.  I'll make this again but next time I'll use garlic powder instead and just salt to taste. Also, 3 tablespoons of oil is just not necessary, I was skimming oil out of the pan when the rice was cooking because I realized it was too much. 1 tablespoon is probably plenty.

text:
I used minute rice instead of reg. rice due to living at a high altitude minute rice works better for me...I didn't have fresh tomatoes so I used 3/4 can of diced tomatoes/juice.  I also used dried cilantro because that's what I had. Didn't use the chicken bullion because I use Tones Chicken stock base which is very rich depending on how much you use. Overall it's been the best Mexican rice I've found, just waiting for the hub's 2 cents ;) I would suggest the original poster explain about cooking the "raw" rice in the skillet and not pre-cook it.

dateLastModified:

country:
None
text:
I think this is a great recipe. I was looking for a simple recipe to go along with some Mexican dishes and this was a hit. I don't typically change anything at least the first time I make something but I did NOT want to stand over the stove and cook rice. I only cook rice in my rice cooker so in order to do that here I sautéed the onion in some butter on the stove and pretty much did everything else the same but added it all to my rice cooker and the machine did the rest. It turned out so great I'm making it again to go with some tacos tonight.

None
text:
This is a delicious recipe. no fail . I used a combination of basmati and sticky rice (that's what I had). Used 2 tsp fresh garlic. Doubled the cumin. Add 1 tsp kosher salt. use butter & olive oil to saute. Saute onions first with cumin. (this brings out the flavor of the cumin) add rice and garlic. You Could add green chilies  if you like! then chicken broth. If you are using bouillon, decrease the kosher salt. I liked it better than my favorite Mexican restaurant rice!

text:
Delicious.  I didn't have tomato sauce but used a half a can of diced tomatoes and lowered the amount of water in the chicken stock to account for the extra liquid in the canned tomatoes.  
The second time I made it during peak tomato season so I chopped up two fresh tomatoes and used two tsp of chicken stock mix with one cup of water.  
My toddler goes nuts for this rice, he has fits while its cooking because it doesn't cook fast enough.  It has become a weekly staple with our Taco Tuesday night.

userID:
7660883
Display Name:
St.PaulMom
isPro:

4

64
favoritesCount:

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:
