photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674152.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
LOVE.THIS.RICE.  Sooooo great.  Don't let the simplicity of the ingredients fool you....this has TONS of flavor if you do it right!  DO NOT use a rice cooker, either!  You must remember to sautee the spices as you brown/toast the rice so the flavors absorb into the rice. So important!  Add some fresh garlic, too!  The toasting of the rice gives it a nutty depth.  Once I forgot to add the spices in this step & added later....didn't taste the same.  Use a good quality chicken broth or cooking stock, as well.  The garlic salt is important, otherwise it'll be too bland.  I also sometimes use El Patio spicy Mexican tomato sauce.  Small yellow can in the Hispanic aisle of your grocery store.  Gives it quite a bit of "punch".  Serve this with grilled fajitas, tamales, enchiladas or tacos for an outstanding side dish.  I like to garnish with fresh lime wedges & chopped cilantro and occasionally add grilled corn kernels.  So amazingly yummy!
Review:
Rating:
5

text:
This is a great starter recipe. After the first time making this I made the following changes. I like the rice sautéd in butter, added fresh minced garlic and the chopped onions once the rice start turning brown.  Put unsalted chicken stock in a large bowl, added petite diced tomatoes, cumin, fresh or dried cilantro, salt and pepper. Stir to mix all the ingredients then add to the rice, let simmer 20/25 minutes.

text:
Excellent recipe as written. I made a few subtle changes due to personal taste.  I used Knorr chicken bouillon dissolved into 2 cups water vs chicken broth, garlic powder to taste vs garlic salt and I cut the onion down to 1/8 cup.  Excellent! I found that cooking it the full 25 minutes was perfect. The rice was not dry at all. This is becoming a staple dish in my home and it has just the right hint of flavor without taking away from the main dish. Perfect.

I used garlic and onion powder instead of garlic salt. If you are from San Diego and miss the taco shop rice, 1/2 a cup of tomato sauce is too much and the rice turns out too red. use a little less and it will turn out awesome!

After trying many Mexican rice recipes on this site and others, this came closest to the "comfort food" Mexican rice that my grandmother in El Paso used to make for me growing up. This is frequently requested in my kitchen!

text:
I’m an “authentic” Tex-Mexican from south Texas and in my opinion this recipe is 100% authentic. I alter my recipe a bit depending on my audience’s taste preferences. For example, I might use 1/4c bell pepper or 2 tomatoes, or ½ c tomato sauce if I don’t have fresh tomatoes, or even ½ tsp garlic salt if I don’t have fresh garlic.  Sometimes, I even omit the jalapenos or chicken bouillon. I recommend following the exact recipe and then altering to your taste preferences or dietary needs/restrictions.

city:

country:
None
text:
DELICIOUS! I only had Jasmin rice on hand. Not sure if it's the same as "Long Grain" or not, but it worked out better in this recipe than the directions on the back! Haha! Every time we cook this rice there are still hard bits in it. No matter what we do. This recipe worked out great though! No hard bits at all! I think it has to do with the browning the rice in the oil first. Anyway, this rice is wonderful! I left out the onion because I started without prepping first, and during the browning you REALLY have to stir constantly or the rice will stick and burn, so I was too preoccupied with the 1st step to cut up the onion. I managed to get everything else in without any disasters. This is diffidently a recipe you want to have all prepared and near by. It was delicious without the onion though! Thanks for sharing the recipe.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I really enjoyed this rice.  It was surprisingly easy, and I've never cooked rice before, but this turned out great.  I didn't use long grain rice, but a Japanese medium grain, but it worked well.  I used olive oil instead of vegetable oil, and I added some minced garlic before I put the rice in.  I also used half of a a chopped white onion, a whole tomato(diced), and a jalapeno(also diced).  Instead of tomato sauce, I used a small can of tomato paste.  I also added fresh cilantro at the end.

text:
Very good! I have made this twice already. The first time I messed up the recipe and cooked the rice instead of letting it puff with the garlic but it still turned out really good. I just drained the water before the rice was cooked all the way and only used half the broth for the remaining cooking time when everything was mixed in. The second time I followed the recipe except I used salsa instead of the tomato paste which already comes with onions, peppers, tomatoes, etc. and that was really good also.

text:
I'm a little more traditional, lived in So Calif, growing up, worked in San Francisco,and when I tretired in 89 move to Mexico, 12 years, San miguel de Allende, as I love cumin, in many Mexican recipes, but nmot Mexican Rice, actually have not seen a Mexican family or Mexican restaurant, (in Mexico) use cumin in Mex. rice.also the redness looks like Spanish rice, I use ripe tomato, or good canned tomato, and only add enough to make rice a little pink not red. But now I'm in North west Montana, Mex food is very basic, most Montana people like a very mild version. So if I delete the cumin it is a good recipe.

country:
None
text:
I've never browned or puffed rice, and it really worked!!  I used Uncle Ben's Whole Grain Fast and Natural Rice (whole grain parboiled brown rice is the only ingredient) and olive oil on medium low heat in a sauce pan (no lid to cover for my skillet).  It took a little while, kind of like popcorn, but it was obvious when the rice "puffed".  After adding the other ingredients and bringing to a boil, cook time was only about 10 more minutes.  Watch it, because it will stick to the bottom of the pan otherwise.  Yummy!  It's on my make again list!!  Thank you!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/66974.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I would give this 4 1/2 stars.  It was easy, didn't take too much effort, used ingredients that I already had on hand and had a good flavor.  I read the other reviews and did make a few minor changes based on reviewer suggestions.  In place of the garlic salt and cumin I used 1-1/2 tsp taco seasoning, added half an onion and half a red bell pepper and used 1 cup chicken broth, 1 cup water.  I will definitely make this again.  I found it to be a little saucy, not runny, but more saucy than the Mexican rice I order in restaurants, so if you want it less saucy you may want to add a bit more rice, or less liquid.
Review:

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
Very good as a simple side.  My husband seasoned up some black beans, and they were very good together.  I do have to admit that I made one change though.  I didn't have any tomato sauce, so I used diced tomatoes with pepper & onion.  I think I would have preferred it with tomato sauce as written, but I was pleased regardless.

* I've made it multiple times now, and though I may prefer it as written, diced tomatoes are almost as good.  I switch based on what I have and if I want little chunks of tomato or not.  I've also been known to make a 4x batch and use some of each.  I love to have this frozen for a quick side for a Mexican dinner.  Tonight it was baked chicken breasts with salsa and a little cheese, some black beans, and this rice.

None
text:
Just what I was looking for, a recipe similar to mine that makes a smaller batch. This recipe yielded tender fluffy rice, better than my other recipe. I omitted the garlic salt and used 3 cloves of fresh minced garlic and added sea salt. I also added in black pepper, a pinch of sugar, frozen peas & carrots, and fresh chopped cilantro. I agree with the reviewer who said that Mexican rice is a side dish meant to accompany the spicier entree and it is supposed to be a little blander, this was what Mexican rice is supposed to be! Thanks for the keeper recipe. I am making it from now on and it is easier than my old recipe too!

text:
I've made this several times following the recipe exactly, and it is delicious exactly as written.  I've also made it using brown rice, and that is good too but not quite as good or authentic as the original recipe.  Last night I tried to use a shortcut by using brown rice and throwing everything in the rice cooker.  That didn't work - the texture was all wrong, and the rice didn't seem to absorb the seasoning as well.  It was edible, but not nearly as good as doing it the old fashioned way.  I'll stick to the recipe from now on.

text:
This rice was very good... I did make some changes though... first I made my rice in a rice cooker and then transfered it to the stove top to simmer with the chicken broth, tomato sauce and spices. I also added a can of Rotel tomatos w/chilis (drained), a little fresh lime juice and cilantro. It was fantastic. Next time I would probably add even more cilantro and lime just for some extra flavor but overall this recipe was a great starting point.

text:
this rice is our families favorite because it is the closest to our favorite authentic mexican restaurant's rice.  yumm-0!  the only change i make is sometimes adding salsa in place of the tomato sauce because i always have salsa on hand & open in the fridge, as opposed to a can of sauce (which tends to go bad in the fridge when opened & not used up quickly).  this flavors it up a bit more, it's milder with plain tomato sauce of course.

text:
This rice was soooooo good and easy!! I made it even more simple by throwing it all in the rice cooker after sauting/browning the rice.  Came out perfect! The ONLY reason why I gave it 4 stars is because I thought it had way to much oil. I doubled the recipe and still only used 3 tablespoons and could still taste it the oily-ness, as could one of my guests.  Next time, i'll halve it again. We eat very clean in our house, maybe thats why. Anyway, this recipe will be the only one i use for mexican rice. very flavorful and super easy!!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Basic, but good.  Saute some fresh garlic w/the onion first, then add rice to brown.  Use the El Pato tomato sauce in the small yellow can for more of a kick.  When rice was done, I added cream of chicken soup, sour cream, a can of corn and about 3/4c of a shredded taco cheese blend, transfer to greased casserole, sprinkle small amount of shredded cheese on top and bake about 25-30 min's at 350.  YUM!!  Very nice starter rice, great for tweaking!

city:

None
country:
None
text:
This rice turned out pretty good considering the fact that I am a terrible cook. W/ some tinkering I think it will be a 5 star. For one, my rice came out a tad bit too wet but I think if I reduce the broth by 1/2 cup since you are adding 1/2 cup tomato sauce it will turn out better. Also, I didn't have time to puff the rice or whatever, I just threw it all in a pot and used dehydrated onions. Still super yummy! I used it as the base to a "naked" burrito bowl. And, don't forget if you are out of garlic salt, substitute 3 parts salt to 1 part garlic powder.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I love this dish because of its easiness. I made a few minor changes based on the reviews. (1) I was worried about the onions not being cooked enough and I was worried about burning the rice so I partially cooked the onions first then added the rice. I also added a bit more onions. (2) I used onion and garlic flavored tomato sauce for added flavor (3) Along with the cumin, I added onion powder, accent, adobo, cayenne pepper, and season all. It ended up being a great side dish and would probably be amazing for burritos.

UPDATE: I realized the first time I made this I accidentally used Swanson's low sodium chicken stock instead of the broth. The 2nd time I used the broth, but I liked the stock better. Also I've added this rice to the Delicious Black Bean Burritos recipe on this site and it was A+!

text:
I was so happy to find this recipe! I LOVED how it turned out and my boyfriend enjoyed it as well.  I've made it a couple time and never make it quite the same each time.  I always add 1/8 tsp of ground cayenne pepper because we like things spicy and helps to give a bit more flavor to the rice.  I also add some fresh minced garlic, a little black pepper as well and double the cumin.  I've also added diced green peppers and added some cubed chicken at the end to make this its own meal rather than a side dish.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674149.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
It is hard to rate a recipe when you end up changing it.  I was concerned about the comments that it needed more flavor so I souped it up.  when I was sauteing the onions, I also sauteed a 1/2 a cup of dived yellow peppers.  Once they were soft I added one TBS of tomato paste.  I used 1 tsp of cumin, 1/2 of chili powder and 1 tsp of taco seasoning (I make my own).  Then added the rice to cover it.  I used vegetable broth instead of water.  I needed more then 1 1/2 c broth, I used 2 1/2 cups.  I also added a third of a cup of chopped tomatoes with their juice instead of the 3 oz chopped tomatoes.  We all loved it.  I will make it this way again.  I may add some peas or black beans at the end next time.

text:
This was super easy and delicious.  I didn't have long grain rice on hand, so I used the Bulk Short Grain rice we have.  I cooked it in our rice cooker and then threw in the tomato sauce (used left over spaghetti sauce), taco seasoning (we didn't have just cumin), only 1/4 c. broth and the cooked rice together in a skillet; it was delicious!  This will be a favorite pick for fast, easy and delicious recipes at our household.

text:
We really loved this dish! I didn't have any cumin on hand, so I just used taco seasoning, as suggested by another reviewer. I used 1 1/2 tsp., but I think next time I'll use a little more. I omitted the garlic salt and just used 1/2 tsp. garlic powder and no salt b/c of the taco seasoning. I made this to go with tacos, but I think it would be great w/ chicken as well. I will definately be making this again! Thanks for posting. :)

text:
Wow! This rice was absolutely delicious! I made it to go into some burritos, and I ended up just eating it by itself in the end. I sauteed the uncooked rice, onions, and spices in the pan until the onions were tender. Then, I threw everything into my rice cooker along with the tomato sauce and chicken stock. I only used 1 3/4 cups of stock and thought it was the perfect amount. The rice came out very tender but not mushy. Thanks so much for this recipe!

I sauted my onions first, then added the rice, constanly stirring.  I added fresh chopped garlic after that for less than a minute to let the aroma come out.  From there I continued with the recipe, using sea salt instead of garlic salt to taste.  It turned out quite well.  I have another rice recipe that I prefer that uses salsa, but this was a good backup.  I will turn to it again when I'm out of salsa but have tomato sauce on hand.

This was a really good recipe.  I bought taco seasoning beforehand b/c some reviewers suggested it. text:
I read reviews that this could be bland, but this rice is great! I'm obsessed with strong flavors and this met the requirement. When I think about the rice I get at Mexican restaurants, it's actually pretty plain, but I mix it with beans and it's perfect. Well this rice is good enough on it's own, and wonderfully simple. Before the entire pot came to a boil, I tossed in a few shakes of oregano and cayenne. I followed the rest of the recipe exactly. I highly recommend this. Also, just a note, I understand we're supposed to rate on the actual recipe, but there's no excuse for bland food when it comes from your own kitchen. Ya gotta love seasonings! :) Thanks for the recipe.

text:
WOW!  I have looked all over the place for a good mexican rice recipe and this is it.  My daughter got seconds.  I put the oil in the bottom of a pot and sauteed the onion and a little bit of green pepper.  I then added the rice and browned and then added the spices.  This was absolutely delicious and mine came out perfect.  I must say that I normally have trouble with a few pieces being hard, but there were no hard pieces.  I let the ingredients all boil for about three minutes and then put the lid on.  I stirred it with nine minutes left of cooking.  FAB!!

Okay.  I'm trying with brown rice tonight.  I'll let you know!

text:
It was really good, instead of regular tomato sauce I used one from the Mexican section called El Pato (Mexican hot style)and it was spicy and delicious, I just used the whole can 7 3/4 ounces, I thought it was 4 ounces, guess I should have worn my reading glasses but it was still really good. It was definately spicy which I like but if your family doesn't just use regular tomato sauce. I will make this again especially with a great soup I recently had in Dallas. Put rice in a bowl, add shredded chicken some tortilla chips, pico de gallo, Monterey Jack cheese, a few slices of avacado and top off with peppery chicken broth and some cilantro, yummmm, this rice is perfect for this.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a pretty traditional Mexican rice recipe, except for the cumin, having grown up in Mexico, I never knew anyone or any place that would add cumin to rice or nearly to any real Mexican dish, this is a Tex-Mex flavor. Real garlic is also used instead of the garlic salt or powdered one.

text:
With a couple of changes, this is the rice recipe we always use when having Mexican. Instead of using a fresh tomato, I use a can of tomatoes with green chilis, drained. I like the extra flavor from the chilis. Instead of the bouillon cube, I use a teaspoon of chicken soup base. All in all, very tasty.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
Yes, this is authentic.  I've been making spanish rice for more than 20 years and this is how it is done.  I would only suggest that you cut the liquid down to 1 3/4 cup if you are using tomato sauce.  
Also, for a once skillet dinner, you can arrange chicken pieces, or diced pork chops over rice after you add the liquid.  Do not open the pan until 20 minutes have passed.  Serve with fresh or refried beans and hot tortillas.  mmmmmm.....

country:
None
text:
I was looking for something to serve with tortillas with a mashed bean filling, and this was just perfect.  It has just enough flavor and not too much.  I didn't have onions or garlic salt, so I put half a teaspoon of regular salt and 1 clove of garlic, chopped into tiny bits.  I also added a few shots of tabasco sauce - my secret ingredient in all Mexican foods.  It gave just a bit of zing and everyone loved this rice.  Next time I'll have fun fooling around with it - I'd love to try it with curry for a more Indian flavor.  Thanks!

text:
This is the Mexican rice recipe I had been looking for :) My friends mother used to make almost the exact same rice. I used to love the smell of the rice sauteing in the oil.
I use minced fresh garlic instead of the garlic salt, and a lil' extra sweet onions, and a lil' extra ground cumin. I usually use only 1/4 c. tomato sauce, also.
My kids love this rice and it is so easy and goes well with all Mexican dishes.
Thanks for the recipe!

text:
This rice was so yummy, Thought I had Cumin but I was all out and had no time to run to the store, Then read a review on here about how someones taco seasoning had cumin in it, I didn't have taco seasoning but i did have Chili seasoning, i put just as much as the cumin called for and it turned out great! My kids and Husband loved it, and my daughter is one picky eater, but she was was asking for seconds!

2873662
Display Name:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1442001.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
We liked this rice much more than any of that store bought stuff.  We have not been able to find anything that tastes halfway decent.  The only reason I am giving this 4 stars is that my liquid did not completely evaporate and it left the rice kinda mushy...I followed the recipe almost exactly except I added some garlic as I was browning the rice.  Next time I will add less  broth. Served in Tacos made w/ the Taco Seasoning I as suggested by another reviewer.  Tasted fantastic together. 

I have since made this again to use in burritos and I reduced the amount of liquid, took off the lid once the rice was no longer hard and let the rest of the liquid evaporate.  I also used diced tomatoes instead of tomato sauce (we liked this much better) and upped the broth  to about 3/4 of a cup.  The rice was great and it tasted even better the second day.But, since I had to make the changes I still can only give it 4 stars....It really tastes authentic w/ the changes and I have made this about once a week.  Used to live in Los Angeles and moved to Colorado...have not been able to find anything, even in restaurants that tastes half as good.  Our rule is "Never Mexican restaurants while in Colorado"

text:
I had to give this recipe 3 stars because of the instructions. I tried to 'puff' the rice as described, and it was a mistake (I should have listened to the other reviews that said not to). The rice didn't puff, and my attempt must have ruined it, because after 45 minutes of cooking, the liquid was still not completely absorbed, and the rice was crunchy and mealy in texture. I will try this recipe again, but without trying to puff the rice. It smelled good - hope it works next time... had to throw it all out ;-(

text:
I'm really pleased with this recipe. I LOVE mexican rice and order it whenever we go out...I couldnt be happier to have found a recipe where I can make my own at home. It was way easier than I thought it would be and my whole house smelled so good. Instead of the can of tomato sauce I used a can of diced tomatoes with jalapenos and also added about 1/4 cup of salsa. I've made this recipe twice now and the ssecond time I realized I was out of canned chicken broth once I had started but I substituted with most of a chicken Ramen seasoning packet and one cup of water. I will definelty be making this regularly.

text:
I never tried to make Mexican rice before...and I am glad I did. I had to make some modifications based on what I had on hand...I usually keep steamed rice in the frig. so I warmed up the oil then added 2 cups of cooked rice, after it warmed up and separated I sprinkled taco seasoning over the rice and added about a 1/2 cup of salsa and a smidge of red taco sauce...all to taste. that was it! And my husband said my home-cooked Mexican food really improved with this recipe.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was pretty good.  I only had jasmine rice, which I wouldn't recommend, because it added a sweetness that countered the dish a bit.  But it was still OK.  Also, I didn't have tomato sauce and I wanted to add green chilies, so I substituted a can of rotel in.  I used chicken bouillon to make the stock and it came out nicely.  Because I boiled the water to dissolved the bouillon, the boiling time for the rice was much less and it was done much faster than the recipe stated.  I'll make this again, but with regular long grain rice.

Display Name:
The Bunny Chef

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/69415.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
For those people who are worried about the rice not "puffing", don't worry about it.  It won't change the outcome of the rice at all.  Just saute it until the grains are nice and golden.  I made this to go with dinner tonight and it was pretty good!  Nice and flavorful.  I only used 1 1/2 cups broth, I think it would have been quite wet if I had used the full amount.  I also sauted the onions a little and then added the rice.  I'm having a difficult time finding a recipe that's just like mexican rice at restaurants, but this is the closest yet!  Next time I'm going to try 1/4 cup tomato sauce (and add 1/4 cup more water, always keeping the liquid at 2 C) and less salt as we found it rather salty.  Thank you for the recipe!

Easy and flavorful-great starter recipe. I made a few changes to suit our personal tastes. I took out the onion. Added 1/2 tsp more cumin.  Also added some chopped jalepenos and green chilie peppers.  Sauteed in some fresh chopped cilantro with the peppers during the oil cooking stage.  Added a little taco sauce at the end when fluffing.  Came out so yummy that even tho we had it 2 nights ago with a mexican dinner-I'm making it again tonight with steaks!

text:
This rice has great flavor!  My rice came out a little crunchy but that was my fault because I used brown rice (although I did increase the cooking time accordingly) and I think I needed a little more liquid.  I added more cumin and chilli powder, onion as others had suggested.  It was a little too salty for my taste so I think next time I will use low sodium chicken broth or maybe use half garlic salt/ half garlic powder.

text:
This wasn't bad but it wasn't that great either.  I gave it four stars for the ease of making the dish.  The only changes that I made were that I used garlic powder instead of garlic salt since I used chicken broth from the store and a few large pinches of dehydrated onion.  The flavor was bland so next time I'd up the garlic, salt, cumin, use real onion and maybe a handful or two of mixed veggies.  My mom who likes everything said that it was "interesting" and my fiance who doesn't like anything (especially onions and tomatoes, he's a freak!)liked it.  So who know's it's worth a try again.
